facts.text: Writ Petition No. 164 of 1958 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No. 164 01 1958. Writ Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by AYYANGAR, J. on April 10, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-The companystitutional validity of the

facts.text: Constitutional validity of operative provisions of Punjab Shops and Commercial Establishments Act, 1958 (Punjab Act 15 of 1958) challenged.

anchor.surface_text: companystitutional validity of the Ay. operative provisions of the Punjab Shops and Commercial Establishments Act, 1958  Punjab Act 15 of 1958 , which we shall hereafter refer to as the Act, is challenged in this writ petition filed under Art. 32

facts.text: First petitioner has a shop at Mandi Dabwali in Hissar District where he carries on wholesale business in purchase and sale of grains.

anchor.surface_text: The first petitioner states that he has a shop at Mandi Dabwali in Hissar District where he carries on business in the purchase and sale of grains, etc. in wholesale.

facts.text: Customers of first petitioner bring goods loaded in carts drawn by camels or bullocks arriving at godowns at all hours of day and night.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant averment in regard to the nature of his business is that the customers who supply him with goods bring them loaded in carts drawn by camels or bullocks and that these vehicles arrive at his godowns at all hours of the day and night.

facts.text: First petitioner receives messages by telephone and telegram during day and night for purchases or sales.

anchor.surface_text: He also states that for the purpose of the purchases or sales effected by him, he receives messages by telephone and telegram both during the day and the night.

facts.text: First petitioner needs to keep place of business open 24 hours to carry on business as before.

anchor.surface_text: These, according to him, render necessary, if he has to carry on business as he has been doing all along, that his place of business should be kept open practically the whole of the day and night, i.e., for all the 24 hours.

facts.text: Second petitioner carries on retail business on small scale, employs no outsider, attends to work himself with family assistance if necessary.

anchor.surface_text: The second petitioner states that he is carrying on a retail business on a small scale, and that he employs numberoutsider but attends to all the work in the shop himself, with the assistance, if necessary, of the members of his family.

facts.text: Goods purchased by second petitioner brought at all hours of day and night, receives messages entire period.

anchor.surface_text: In this case also it is stated that the goods purchased are brought to him at all hours of the day and night and similarly he has to receive messages during the entire period.

facts.text: Act received assent of President on April 25, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Act received the assent of the President on April 25, 1958, and was published in the Punjab Gazette on May 1, 1958.

facts.text: Act published in Punjab Gazette on May 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Act received the assent of the President on April 25, 1958, and was published in the Punjab Gazette on May 1, 1958.

facts.text: Act came into force on June 1, 1958 by notification.

anchor.surface_text: Section 1 3  of the Act provides that the Act shall companye into force on such date as Government may, by numberification appoint in this behalf and by a numberification under this provision the Act was directed to companye into force from June 1, 1958.

facts.text: Mandi Dabwali is in the Schedule, Act applies there in first instance.

anchor.surface_text: Mandi Dabwali where the petitioners carry on business is one of the local areas in the district of Hissar set out in the Schedule annexed.

facts.text: Petitioners' main grievance: Act not brought into force in neighbouring local areas.

anchor.surface_text: We might here numbere that the main grievance of the petitioners appears to, be that it has number been brought into force in neighbouring local areas

facts.text: Act repeals and re-enacts with modifications the Punjab Trade Employees Act, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The Act repealed and re-enacted, with modifications, the Punjab Trade Employees Act, 1940, to which enactment also it would be necessary to advert in its proper place.

facts.text: Section 7 limits employment to 48 hours per week and 9 hours per day.

anchor.surface_text: Hours of employment.-- 1  Subject to the provisions of this Act, numberperson shall be employed about the business of an establishment for more than forty-eight hours in any one week, and nine hours in any one day.

facts.text: Section 9 sets opening no earlier than 10 AM, closing no later than 8 PM, with provisos.

anchor.surface_text: Opening and closing hours.-- No establishment shall, save as otherwise provided by this Act, open earlier than ten oclock in the morning or close later than eight oclock in the evening Provided that any customer who was in the establishment before the closing hour may be served during the period of fifteen minutes immediately following such hour

facts.text: Section 10 requires every establishment to remain closed on every Sunday, with exceptions.

anchor.surface_text: Close day.- 1  Save as otherwise provided by this Act, every establishment shall remain close on every Sunday Provided that, in the case of an establishment attached to a factory, the employer may substitute the close day of such establishment

facts.text: State Government notification dated June 1, 1958 exempted certain establishments from ss.9 and 10.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly by numberification of the State Government State dated June 1, 1958, the following classes of establishments wer exempted from the provisions of SS. 9 and 10  1  establishments dealing in the retail sale of Phullian, Murmura, sugar-coated grams and Reoris

facts.text: Petitioners argue restrictions impossible given nature of business, unreasonable under Art.19(6).

anchor.surface_text: It is urged by Mr. Chatterji--learned Counsel for the petitioners-that having regard to the nature of the petitioners business, whose features we have set out earlier, it would be impossible for them to carry it on in the manner in which they have been doing up to number, unless the Act permitted

facts.text: Court holds provisions do not impose unreasonable restrictions, valid under Art.19(6).

anchor.surface_text: Judged by this test, neither the 48-hour week, number the specification of the opening and closing hours can be said to have gone beyond what by modern standards are necessary for ensuring the health and efficiency of the employee.

facts.text: Prior decision in Manohar Lal v. State of Punjab delivered November 11, 1960 upholds similar provision.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, this point regarding restrictions of this nature being unreasonable is companycluded against the petitioners by the decision of this Court in Manohar Lal v. The State of Punjab  1  judgment on which was delivered on November 11, 1960.

facts.text: C. Chatterjee and Naunit Lal appeared for petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: C. Chatterjee and Naunit Lal, for the petitioners. S. Bindra and D. Gupta, for the respondent.

facts.text: S. Bindra and D. Gupta appeared for respondent.

anchor.surface_text: C. Chatterjee and Naunit Lal, for the petitioners. S. Bindra and D. Gupta, for the respondent. 1961. April 10.

anchor.surface_text: The Act received the assent of the President on April 25, 1958, and was published in the Punjab Gazette on May 1, 1958. Section 1 3  of the Act provides that the Act shall companye into force on such date as Government may, by numberification appoint in this behalf and by a numberification under this provision the Act was directed to companye into force from June 1, 1958.

Section 1 3  of the Act provides that the Act shall companye into force on such date as Government may, by numberification appoint in this behalf and by a numberification under this provision the Act was directed to companye into force from June 1, 1958. The Act, however,, did number of its own force apply to the entirety of the Punjab State, for s. 1 4  enacted 1 4 . It shall apply in the first instance to the areas specified in the Schedule

Section 2 iv  defines a a companymercial establishment to which the Act applies as meaning any premises wherein any business, trade or profession is carried on for profit, omitting the unnecessary words.
Section 2 v  defines day as meaning the period of twenty-four hours beginning at midnight, again omitting what is immaterial.
The Act repealed and re-enacted, with modifications, the Punjab Trade Employees Act, 1940, to which enactment also it would be necessary to advert in its proper place.

anchor.surface_text: The Act, however,, did number of its own force apply to the entirety of the Punjab State, for s. 1 4  enacted 1 4 . It shall apply in the first instance to the areas specified in the Schedule [...] We might here mention that the main grievance of the petitioners appears to, be that it has number been brought into force in neighbouring local areas and that this disparity in the regulations is acting to the disadvantage of people carrying on business in the areas set out in the Schedule.

arguments.claim: Selective application of the Act only to scheduled areas like Mandi Dabwali but not to neighbouring local areas creates disparity that disadvantages petitioners and constitutes a constitutional grievance.

anchor.surface_text: Mandi Dabwali where the petitioners carry on business is one of the local areas in the district of Hissar set out in the Schedule annexed. arguments.claim: Restrictions under sections 7 and 9 make it impossible for petitioners to carry on their business in the manner they have been doing, constituting unreasonable restrictions under Article 19(6).

anchor.surface_text: It is urged by Mr. Chatterji--learned Counsel for the petitioners-that having regard to the nature of the petitioners business, whose features we have set out earlier, it would be impossible for them to carry it on in the manner in which they have been doing up to number, unless the Act permitted

arguments.court_reasoning: Restrictions necessary for worker health and efficiency, do not exceed modern standards; supported by precedent.

arguments.claim: Public and social interest in the health and efficiency of workers is paramount and justifies regulation of working conditions.

anchor.surface_text: The regulation of contracts of labour so as to ameliorate their conditions of work is in reality a problem of human relationship and social control for the advancement of the community. The public and social interest in the health and efficiency of the worker is, at the present day, beyond challenge.

arguments.claim: Indian Constitution does not protect impairment of contracts like US Constitution Article 1 s.10(1); test is whether restrictions for worker welfare are unreasonable from employer's view.

anchor.surface_text: Our Constitution does number protect or guarantee any fundamental right in the nature of the provision in Art. 1, s. 10 1 , of the U. S. Constitution against impairment of the obligation of contracts. The only test of constitutional validity therefore is whether the provision in the impugned law

arguments.claim: 48-hour week and opening/closing hours (ss.7,9) are reasonable as they do not exceed what is necessary for worker health and efficiency by modern standards.

anchor.surface_text: Judged by this test, neither the 48-hour week, number the specification of the opening and closing hours can be said to have gone beyond what by modern standards are necessary for ensuring the health and efficiency of the employee.

arguments.claim: Concept of necessary welfare measures for labour is dynamic, reflecting evolving social conscience.

anchor.surface_text: It might also be added that the concept of what is necessary to secure the welfare of labour, or indeed of the elements which determine its content are neither of them fixed or static, but are dynamic, being merely the manifestation or index of the social conscience as it grows and develops from time to time.

arguments.claim: Restrictions upheld by binding precedent in Manohar Lal v. State of Punjab (1960) on similar weekly closure provision.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, this point regarding restrictions of this nature being unreasonable is concluded against the petitioners by the decision of this Court in Manohar Lal v. The State of Punjab  1  judgment on which was delivered on November 11, 1960.

arguments.claim: Scheme of exemptions (s.4, notifications, provisos to s.9) and categories of establishments shows balanced approach, rendering restrictions reasonable in context.

anchor.surface_text: the first head is dealt with by s. 4 of the Act which reads Provisions of sections 9 and 10 number applicable to certain establishments.-Nothing in sections 9 and 10 shall apply to-  a  clubs, hotels, boarding houses, stalls and refreshment rooms at the railway stations

arguments.claim: Even for small traders without employees, restrictions valid as per Manohar Lal: protects owner's health, prevents evasion, reasonable margin for enforcement.

holdings.text: This, however, cannot obviously be a ground of constitutional grievance.

anchor.surface_text: This, however, cannot obviously be a ground of constitutional grievance and learned Counsel therefore very properly did not rely on it except merely to draw our attention to this fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Selective enforcement in scheduled areas versus neighbors does not violate Constitution; counsel did not press the point.

holdings.text: Judged by this test, neither the 48-hour week, nor the specification of the opening and closing hours can be said to have gone beyond what by modern standards are necessary for ensuring the health and efficiency of the employee.

anchor.surface_text: Judged by this test, neither the 48-hour week, nor the specification of the opening and closing hours can be said to have gone beyond what by modern standards are necessary for ensuring the health and efficiency of the employee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restrictions under ss.7 and 9 are reasonable as they align with modern standards for worker health, efficiency, and leisure; judged from employer viewpoint but prioritizing public interest.

holdings.text: The only test of constitutional validity therefore is whether the provision in the impugned law, which is enacted to avoid physical overstrain of the worker, and so as to afford him better conditions of work, and more regulated hours, thus ensuring to him a reasonable amount of leisure--factors which would render the restrictions in the interest of the general public, is unreasonable from the point of view of the employer.

anchor.surface_text: The public and social interest in the health and efficiency of the worker is, at the present day, beyond challenge. Our Constitution does not protect or guarantee any fundamental right in the nature of the provision in Art. 1, s. 10(1), of the U. S. Constitution against impairment of the obligation of contracts. The only test of constitutional validity therefore is whether the provision in the impugned law

holdings.reasoning_summary: Articulates reasonableness test under Art.19(6): restrictions valid if necessary for worker welfare without excess; no contracts clause protection in Indian Constitution.

holdings.text: Besides, this point regarding restrictions of this nature being unreasonable is concluded against the petitioners by the decision of this Court in Manohar Lal v. The State of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, this point regarding restrictions of this nature being unreasonable is concluded against the petitioners by the decision of this Court in Manohar Lal v. The State of Punjab 1 judgment on which was delivered on November 11, 1960.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Binding precedent in Manohar Lal upholds similar weekly closure as reasonable under Art.19(6), even for small owner-operated shops.

holdings.text: These observations, in our opinion, clearly apply and suffice to support the validity of the related provisions here impugned.

anchor.surface_text: These observations, in our opinion, clearly apply and suffice to support the validity of the related provisions here impugned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Manohar Lal reasoning on social interest in worker health, owner welfare, and preventing evasion applies to ss.7,9 even for petitioner-like businesses without employees.

precedents.citation: Manohar Lal v. The State of Punjab  1

anchor.surface_text: Manohar Lal v. The State of Punjab  1 judgment on which was delivered on November 11, 1960.

precedents.case_name: Manohar Lal v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Restrictions of this nature on shops and establishments, such as weekly closing, are reasonable and do not violate Article 19(6) as they serve social interest in worker health, owner welfare, and prevent evasion of labor protections.
precedents.cited_holding: The ratio of the legislation is social interest in the health of the worker who forms an essential part of the community... The inclusion of a reasonable margin to ensure effective enforcement will not stamp a law otherwise valid as within legislative competence with the character of unconstitutionality as being unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: 1 1961 2 S.C.R. 343. be reasonable, if the same were necessary to secure the efficient enforcement of valid provisions. The inclusion of a reasonable margin to ensure effective enforcement will number stamp a law otherwise valid as within legislative companypetence with the character of unconstitutionality as being unreasonable.

precedents.case_name: Manohar Lal v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Restrictions innocent in themselves may be prohibited if necessary for effective enforcement of valid labor provisions, and a reasonable margin for enforcement does not render the law unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: These observations, in our opinion, clearly apply and suffice to support the validity of the related provisions here impugned.

outcome.relief_summary: Constitutional validity of ss. 7 and 9 of the Punjab Shops and Commercial Establishments Act, 1958 upheld; challenge rejected
